components.content: With this tool, using a drag-and-drop interface and predefined blocks, you can build an HTML email template that is safe to use in email clients. The result is responsive. Using the preview mode, you can see what the email will look like on different devices. The generated MJML markup gets translated into HTML, which you can use in your emails. The project state is saved in a JSON file that contains all the settings and images that you're using in the project and can be imported back into the app. Your changes will also be automatically saved in the browser to prevent data loss.
To paste the email into Outlook, click "
" and paste the contents into a new message.
If the formatting looks wrong, in Outlook, search for the option "Set default paste" and set "Pasting from other apps" to "Keep source formatting"
. Another option is to use a third-party plugin, such as
, and paste the exported HTML code there.
You can customize the styles of any component using the settings in the
, you can change the HTML attributes of a component, for example the alt attribute to provide alt text for images or the href attribute to turn something into a link. The
panel shows how the components are nested within each other. This can be useful when trying to locate a layout issue. The final panel,
, contains all the blocks that you can drag into the email. Generally, sections with text and images should be wrapped in columns.
You can use standard keyboard shortcuts to work with the project:
• Ctrl + Shift + Z or ⌘ + Shift + Z to

You can provide source URLs for the images, or upload them from your drive directly. In that case, they will be scaled to a maximum resolution (600px × 400px) and embedded into the document. To keep the size of the document smaller, it is recommended to host the images somewhere else and only provide the URLs.
Double click on a placeholder image to open the

. The images that are uploaded from a drive get saved in the project file automatically and will get retrieved when you load the project again from a file or from the autosave. In addition to adding images into the body of the email., you can also change the background image of any component.

Tables aren't responsive, but they guarantee that the columns won't collapse into rows. Tables only accept components from the Table section. When working with tables, it may be convenient to toggle on component borders in the Toolbar.
